awd_titl_txt: Macro-Level Sources of Illegal Drug Overdose Deaths across U.S. Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Between 1999 and 2016, the United States experienced a three-fold increase in illegal drug overdose deaths, with many communities facing epidemic levels of overdoses.  As a result, overdose deaths now claim three to four times more American lives each year than homicide and more deaths annually than the AIDS epidemic did at its peak.  Although the drug overdose crisis has affected people across all locations and walks of life, research shows that this illegal drug epidemic is concentrated in some communities and demographic groups but not others.  Little research has been conducted, however, on why some places and populations are more vulnerable to experiencing drug overdoses.  In addition, little is known about whether the community sources of fatal drug overdoses are the same as those that shape homicide and suicide rates.  This project will address these questions by identifying the community characteristics that contribute to drug overdose death concentrations across locales, time, and demographic groups, both alone and compared to the community sources of homicide and suicide.  In so doing, this project provides one of the most comprehensive, nationwide analyses examining the community-level sources of drug overdose deaths to date.  It also will equip researchers and policy makers with information that can be used to combat the drug overdose epidemic by targeting community-level conditions for intervention and assisting those places and groups that are most susceptible to drug overdose concentrations.  

  

This project will compile a unique database using approximately 25 years of nationally-representative mortality data on overdose deaths, homicides, and suicides drawn from the Center for Disease Control Restricted-Access Multiple Cause of Death Mortality data from 1990 to 2016.  These data will be aggregated and combined with measures of community social, economic, and health indicators drawn from multiple databases including: the U.S. Census Bureau, Center for Disease Control prescription data, and Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation community health data.  Using fixed effects change-score models, these combined data will be used to identify the community sources of overdose death rates across: (1) aggregate study units (e.g., county, metropolitan areas); (2) time (1990-2016); (3) substance type (heroin, natural and semi-synthetic opioids, synthetic opioids, cocaine, psychostimulants); and (4) demographic groups (race/ethnicity, age, gender).  These analyses will be replicated for both homicide and suicide to identify whether the community-level determinants of death are unique for each form of mortality, or whether there are common factors that similarly predict overdose, homicide, and suicide death rates.  Hybrid time series models will also be used to address limitations of fixed effects modeling.  Findings from this project will contribute to greater understanding of ecological theories of crime by testing relevant hypotheses using dependent variables reflecting drug overdose, homicide, and suicide rates, which include outcomes previously understudied within this theoretical framework.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of this project was to develop a macro-level understanding of drug overdose deaths, both alone and compared to the aggregate-level sources of homicide and suicide concentrations.  Specifically, this project sought to identify the community characteristics that contribute to drug overdose death concentrations across (1) aggregate study units (county, metropolitan areas), (2) time (1990-2016), (3) substance type (heroin, natural and semi-synthetic opioids, fentanyl and synthetic opioids, cocaine, etc.), and (4) demographic groups (race/ethnicity, age, gender, foreign-born contexts).  In addition, these macro-level analyses were replicated for both homicide and suicide in order to identify whether the community-level determinants of death are unique for each form of mortality or whether there are common factors drawn from the leading ecological theories of crime and drug deaths that predict overdose, homicide, and suicide death rates.

The macro-level dataset developed for this project includes approximately 25 years of nationally-representative mortality data on overdose deaths, homicides, and suicides drawn from the Center for Disease Control's (CDC) Restricted-Access Multiple Cause of Death Mortality data files from 1990 to 2016.  This project aggregated millions of individual death records drawn from these files to create the mortality rates examined here.  These data were then combined with measures of community social, economic, legal, and health indicators drawn from nearly a dozen additional databases, including:  U.S. Census Bureau, Robert Wood Johnson Foundation Community Health Rankings, Medicaid Part D Prescription data, U.S. County Business Patterns data, DEA ARCOS data on drug dispersal rates, FBI Law Enforcement data, Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation County Profile Data, and CDC data on healthcare, illness, and treatment patterns of locales (among others). 

 

The data and research from this project provide some of the most comprehensive information available on macro-level overdose, homicide, and suicide patterns alongside information on community social, economic, legal, and health contexts with nationwide coverage over time.  The results of this research also provide some of the most detailed analyses to date aimed at identifying the community risk factors that make counties and other macro-level contexts more or less vulnerable to concentrations of overdose, homicide, and suicide over time.  The results of this research indicate that overdose death concentrations are linked to three macro-level narratives or theories on the overdose epidemic - "dug opportunity-availability," "community patterns of despair," and "community health problems."  In addition, results indicate that several of these factors are also linked to increased homicide and suicide rates (e.g., loss of manufacturing jobs, population decline), suggesting that there may be some general determinants of death that contribute to multiple fatal problems across communities.

In addition, work from this project addresses theory, public concerns, and discourse about the magnitude of the overdose crisis and whether factors, such as immigration, have contributed to community concentrations of overdose deaths.  Results suggest that the public continues to underestimate the magnitude and severity of the overdose crisis.  In addition, and similar to research examining immigration and violence, this research also shows that communities with growing levels of immigration have either similar or lower levels of overdose deaths and homicide than those without growing immigrant concentrations.  As such, our work extends "immigrant revitalization" theories and suggests that immigration may have broad or general insulating effects that protect communities from a range of social problems, including overdose mortality and homicide.
